media_caption: Ricky Davao in Palasyo ni Valentin, College of Saint Benilde, 2015
text_description: Palasyo ni Valentin by O’Hara is first staged, under the direction of Tony Mabesa, by the UP Playwrights Theater at UP Diliman.
The Japanese re-constitute the Board of Review for Moving Pictures (BRMP).
DZBB goes on the air.

Songs and slogans promoting Marcos and martial rule begin to air. Among these are the march Bagong Pagsilang, also known as the March of the New Society, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon (1912-1992) and lyrics by Levi Celerio (1910-2002); and the slogan "Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan.
Philippine radio stations air news about the bombing of Pearl Harbor and, hours later, the Philippines.
CBN launches DZXL.
RA 7306 grants PTV 4 a charter.
The first known radio broadcast experiment in the Philippines is conducted by a Mrs Redgrave at Nichols Air Base.
Henry Herman begins test broadcasts from three stations, which are later consolidated into KZKZ under the Radio Corporation of the Philippines (RCP).
KZRC airs in Cebu, the first outside Manila.

media_caption: Gen. Douglas MacArthur (Photo from xiaochua.net)
text_description: Before retreating to Corregidor, Gen Douglas MacArthur orders the destruction of radio equipment. Some KZRH equipment is brought to Corregidor while other pieces are hidden in the Jai-Alai building on Taft Avenue.

media_caption: Soldiers listening to Voice of Freedom (Photo from xiaochua.net)
text_description: Filipino-American forces broadcast from the Voice of Freedom in Corregidor. KZRC relays its signals.

media_caption: Bataan Death March (Photo from xiaochua.net)
text_description: On the Voice of Freedom, Norman Reyes reads the historic announcement "Bataan Has Fallen," written by Salvador P Lopez, and translated and read in Tagalog by Francisco Isidoro.
The Japanese order Maj Gen Jonathan Wainwright to announce on KZRH the surrender of the Philippine-American forces to the Japanese.
Aawitan Kita, a weekly musical TV show, begins airing on KBS Channel 9. It airs for 36 years on different channels.
CBN airs the first live cooking show on TV, Lets Cook with Nora, hosted by Nora Daza, later renamed Cooking It Up with Nora, enjoying a 25-year run.
The musical variety program Superstar, hosted by Nora Aunor, begins its 18-year run on Channel 9.
ABS-CBN Channel 2 covers the bombing of  the Liberal Party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda.
Sen Benigno Aquino Jr aka Ninoy guests on Maximo Solivens program Impact on ABS-CBN Channel 2 to expose the plan of Pres Ferdinand Marcos to declare martial law, called Operation Sagittarius.
Channels 7 and 13 resume broadcast while Channels 2, 4, 5, and 11 remain off the air. Local TV programs, with new titles that reflect what Marcos calls the New Society, are allowed to go on air.

media_caption: Eat Bulaga hosts Tito, Vic, and Joey
text_description: Blocktimer Television and Production Exponents (TAPE Inc.) launches Eat Bulaga! on RPN 9.
GMA 7 airs Lovingly Yours Helen, a drama anthology based on letters sent by viewers.

media_caption: Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos declaring Proclamation 1081, 23 Sep 1972
media_credit: (Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)
text_description: Pres Marcos announces the declaration of martial law at 7:15 pm on KBS Channel 9 and DZRP. He padlocks broadcast stations and newspaper operations, except the Benedicto-owned KBS, the Philippine Daily Express, and DZRP.
DZRV airs the only blow-by-blow account of Aquinos arrival, with its correspondent annotating the events through a pay phone.
The longest running childrens show Batibot airs on RPN 9.
Pres Ferdinand Marcos announces on This Week with David Brinkley on American ABC-TV that a presidential snap election will be held.
The long-running teen-oriented variety show Thats Entertainment airs on GMA 7.

Juan Ponce Enrile asks DZRV to cover the announcement of his, and Fidel V. Ramoss, break with Pres Ferdinand Marcos. Cardinal Sin calls people via DZRV to protect Enrile and Ramos. By nightfall a siege is underway. Initially, only DZRV covers the event live, but provincial and foreign stations carry its signals.

media_caption: Joaquin Miguel Elizalde, one of the founders of the Manila Broadcasting Company
text_description: A new KZRH is back on the air under Joaquin and Manuel Elizaldes Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC).

text_headline: RCP merges with Far Eastern Radio Inc (FERI).
text_description: RCP merges with Far Eastern Radio Inc (FERI).

text_headline: The Rich Man’s Daughter, a telenovela on lesbian characters, airs on GMA7.
text_description: The Rich Man’s Daughter, a telenovela on lesbian characters, airs on GMA7.

text_headline: My Husband’s Lover, a telenovela on gay characters and dilemmas, airs on GMA7.
text_description: My Husband’s Lover, a telenovela on gay characters and dilemmas, airs on GMA7.
Upon Gen Douglas MacArthurs landing, the Voice of Freedom operates under the call letters WVLC from Leyte.

text_headline: CNN Philippines airs on Channel 9 under license by Turner Broadcasting System.
text_description: CNN Philippines airs on Channel 9 under license by Turner Broadcasting System.

text_headline: The MTRCB orders ABS-CBN to attend a mandatory conference on gender sensitivity
text_description: The MTRCB orders ABS-CBN to attend a mandatory conference on gender sensitivity following the condemnation by the Philippine Commission on Women of the June 4 episode of the reality show Pinoy Big Brother: All In, where program participants are instructed to participate in a nude painting activity.

text_headline: The Supreme Court of the Philippines declares the major provisions of the Cybercrime Prevention Act of 2012, including the online libel provision, as constitutional.
text_description: The Supreme Court of the Philippines declares the major provisions of the Cybercrime Prevention Act of 2012, including the online libel provision, as constitutional.

text_headline: The Human Rights Watch notes that in 2013, 12 journalists in the Philippines are killed, the highest number in a single year since 2009.
text_description: The Human Rights Watch notes that in 2013, 12 journalists in the Philippines are killed, the highest number in a single year since 2009.

text_headline: The MTRCB adds the SPG (Striktong Patnubay at Gabay, or Strict Parental Guidance) classification to TV programs.
text_description: The MTRCB adds the SPG (Striktong Patnubay at Gabay, or Strict Parental Guidance) classification to TV programs.

text_headline: TV5 partners with Cignal Digital TV for cable and satellite TV
text_description: TV5 partners with Cignal Digital TV for cable and satellite TV, including the channels Colours for lifestyle and reality shows, Hyper for sports and entertainment, and Bloomberg TV, a business news channel. TV 5 archives and airs programs on Fox Filipino.

text_headline: GMA News TV Channel 27 replaces QTV-11 and Channel Q.
text_description: GMA News TV Channel 27 replaces QTV-11 and Channel Q.

text_headline: The “macho dance” controversy involving a minor on the Willing Willie show on ABC 5 sparks outrage among activist groups and ordinary citizens.
text_description: The “macho dance” controversy involving a minor on the Willing Willie show on ABC 5 sparks outrage among activist groups and ordinary citizens.

text_headline: Pres Aquino puts the NTC under the Office of the President.
text_description: Pres Aquino puts the NTC under the Office of the President.

text_headline: NBN re-introduces its brand name People’s Television or PTV4.
text_description: NBN re-introduces its brand name People’s Television or PTV4.

text_headline: Media Quest shifts FM programming from mainly music to news and talk, a format traditionally used in AM radio.
text_description: Media Quest shifts FM programming from mainly music to news and talk, a format traditionally used in AM radio.

media_caption: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of National Economic Protectionism Association)
text_description: Isaac Beck puts up KZIB.

media_caption: KDKA studio, 1935
text_description: The first commercial radio broadcast in the US airs in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

media_caption: KZRH first aired from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila before World War II
text_description: H. E. Heacock Co. opens KZRH.

media_caption: Atang de la Rama
text_description: Filipino music gains renewed popularity as artists like Atang de la Rama (1905-1991) sing the kundiman on the air.

media_caption: “Reconditioning” or reconfiguration of radio sets
text_description: The Japanese order the “reconditioning” of shortwave radio receivers to receive only authorized broadcasts.

media_caption: Rajio Taiso, a 15-minute calisthenics program aired over Japanese-controlled radio
text_description: Rajio Taiso, a daily calisthenics program, starts airing. All government employees and schoolchildren are required to follow.

media_caption: Print advertisement of models of radio sets, with both long wave and short wave receivers, 1938
text_description: KZRH announces that radio sets must be registered with the Customs office. Defiance of the order is punishable by torture or death.

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, one of the announcers on KZRC-Voice of Freedom
text_description: Filipino-American forces broadcast from the Voice of Freedom in Corregidor. KZRC relays its signals.

media_caption: Jose P. Laurel being sworn in as president of the Japanese-sponsored Philippine republic, 1943, aired over radio station PIAM
media_credit: (Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)
text_description: Jose P Laurel is inaugurated President of the Republic of the Philippines. Thus, until the end of the war, the Philippines has two presidents.

media_caption: Pres Manuel Roxas speaking on live broadcast during the declaration of Philippine Independence, 1946, as Vice Pres Elpidio Quirino, seated at left, looks on (Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)
media_credit: (Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)
text_description: Philippine Independence from the US is declared. Pres Roxas is inaugurated as the first President of the third Republic of the Philippines.

media_caption: DZFX at the top of Insular Life Building, Ayala Avenue, ca 1960
text_description: DZFX airs and becomes the first successful FM station in RP with high fidelity stereophonic sound.

media_caption: Judge Antonio Quirino, founder of DZAQ-TV
text_description: Judge Antonio Quirino, brother of Pres Quirino, buys the controlling shares of BEC and re-names it Alto Broadcasting System (ABS). It will be used for the latter’s re-election campaign.

media_caption: James Lindenberg, regarded as one of the pioneers of commercial television in the Philippines
text_description: James Lindenberg establishes Bolinao Electronics Company (BEC).

media_caption: Portrait of Don Eugenio H. Lopez Sr aka Eñing, 1957
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Eugenio Lopez Sr acquires the news daily The Manila Chronicle. It will later lend its name to the first Lopez broadcast company, the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN).

media_caption: Chronicle Broadcasting Network Building, Aduana Street, Intramuros, Manila, 1955
text_description: Lopez Sr. obtains a radio and TV franchise under Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). With The Manila Chronicle, he becomes the first in tri-media ownership.

media_caption: ABS building on Dewey Boulevard, Pasay City, 1960
text_description: Lopez Sr. buys ABS from Quirino and Lindenberg.

media_caption: Don Joaquin “Chino” Roces, owner of Associated Broadcasting Corporation
text_description: The Roces family, publisher of the newspaper The Manila Times, establishes the television station DZMT Channel 5 under the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

media_caption: KBS-9: Accucolor 9 logo, 1969-1971
text_description: The Benedicto family, publisher of the newspaper Philippine Daily Express, establishes DZKB under Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS).

media_caption: Manila Broadcasting Company logo, 1970-1971
text_description: MBC-TV Channel 11 goes on the air with the first TV news program in Tagalog, Ano ang Balita.

media_caption: Interisland Broadcasting Corporation logo, 1960-1975
text_description: IBC-TV 13 makes its premiere telecast.

media_caption: Tawag ng Tanghalan hosts Patsy and Lopito with winners, Bing Martinez and Lerrie Pangilinan, 1960
text_description: Tawag ng Tanghalan airs on DZBB.

media_caption: Print advertisement of Salamisim, ca 1968
text_description: The drama anthology Salamisim airs on ABC 5.

media_caption: Scene from Sineskwela, 1994
text_description: The curriculum-based educational program Sineskwela airs on ABS-CBN, the Knowledge Channel, and The Filipino Channel.

media_caption: Gabriel “Flash” Elorde and Harold Gomes during their historic fight, 1960
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Elorde Gilmore Boxing Gym)
text_description: The World Lightweight Boxing Championship match between Gabriel “Flash” Elorde and Harold Gomes is aired on Channel 3. Elorde wins the title

media_caption: Broadcaster Rafael Yabut
text_description: Rafael “Paeng” Yabut (1925-1997) inserts his stinging news commentary in the music program Tayo’y Mag-aliw and begins the tradition of fiery social and political criticism on the air.

media_caption: Chiquito and Yolanda Guevarra in a scene from the movie adaptation of Gorio and His Jeepney, 1962
text_description: The sitcom Gorio and His Jeepney airs on ABC 5.

media_caption: Media man Joaquin “Chino” Roces of Manila Times and the Associated Broadcasting Corporation, third from left, together with anti-Marcos politicians and media men, from left, Teodoro Locsin Sr, Francisco “Soc” Rodrigo, Jose “Joe” Mari Velez, Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr, Napoleon “Nap” Rama, Jose “Pepe” W. Diokno, and Ramon “Monching” Mitra.
text_description: Several opposition leaders and media persons are arrested and incarcerated, including Ninoy Aquino, Jose Diokno, Chino Roces, Teodoro Locsin Sr, Max Soliven, Jose Mari Velez, and Soc Rodrigo. Other media persons are later arrested.

media_caption: Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas representatives paying a courtesy call on Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, ca 1974.
text_description: The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP), later Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, is organized by leaders of the broadcast media industry. It is among the means the martial law government used to control the media. It will operate independently when Marcos rule ends.

media_caption: Martial law propaganda poster, 1973
text_description: Songs and slogans promoting Marcos and martial rule begin to air. Among these are the march Bagong Pagsilang, also known as the March of the New Society, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon (1912-1992) and lyrics by Levi Celerio (1910-2002); and the slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan."

media_caption: RMN-IBC 13 Print advertisement of its relaunch
text_description: Andres Soriano Sr, publisher of The Philippines Herald, buys IBC-TV 13 from Dick Baldwin and RMN from the Canoy brothers. He establishes DZHP radio in Manila under RMN-IBC.

media_caption: Corazon Aquino and Dong Puno in Viewpoint, ca 1986
media_credit: (GMA Gold: 50 Years of Broadcast History edited by Chelo Banal-Formoso. GMA Network, 2001.)
text_description: The current affairs debate show Dong Puno Live, later Dong Puno Tonight, airs on ABS-CBN 2.

media_caption: Benigno Aquino, left, on Face the Nation, with host Ronnie Nathanielsz, 10 Mar 1978
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Ninoy and Cory Foundation)
text_description: Journalists interview Aquino live from Fort Bonifacio on the talk show Face the Nation on GTV 4.

media_caption: Cebuano radio journalist Nenita “Inday Nita” Cortes-Daluz of DYRC, 1986
text_description: Stories covering anti-Marcos rallies begin to air more frequently. In Cebu, popular radio personality Inday Nita Cortes-Daluz (1938-2007) is jailed after joining and covering demonstrations decrying the murder of Ninoy Aquino.

media_caption: Imelda Marcos, center, with the winner and candidates of Miss Universe 1974
text_description: RPN 9 airs the 23rd Miss Universe pageant held at the Folk Arts Theater in Manila, with simultaneous international broadcasts.

media_caption: June Keithley, seated at the background, with Paolo and Gabe Mercado, seated at the foreground, during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: The DZRV transmitter is bombed presumably by Marcos partisans. Its broadcast moves to DZRJ on Santa Mesa, identifies itself as Radyo Bandido, and begins broadcast with Mambo Magsaysay. Meanwhile, DZRH airs Marcos’s press conference where he declares he is in control of the situation.

media_caption: 9TV and CNN anchors and executives during the CNN Philippines launch, 2014
text_description: CNN Philippines airs on Channel 9 under license by Turner Broadcasting System.

media_caption: Original MYX VJs Iya Villania, left, Luis Manzano, and Nikki Gil at the MYX MO! Festival, 2008
text_description: ABS-CBN establishes MYX, the first Filipino 24/7 music channel, on SKYcable.

media_caption: Pioneering hosts and producers of The Probe Team Luchi Cruz-Valdes, left, Maria Ressa, and Cheche Lazaro, 2009
text_description: Probe pioneers investigative broadcast journalism in the country and airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Scene from Ditsi Carolino’s Minsan Lang Sila Bata, 1996
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Ateneo Center for Social Policy)
text_description: Minsan Lang Sila Bata, a documentary on child labor, airs on GMA 7.

media_caption: Hamon ng Kalikasan: Climate Change advertisement, 2012
text_description: GMA7’s Hamon ng Kalikasan goes on the air as the first meteorology program in the Philippines.

media_caption: Si Juan Tamad print advertisement
media_credit: (The Cinema of Manuel Conde by Nicanor G. Tiongson. University of Santo Tomas Publishing House, 2008.)
text_description: In the absence of pre-war commercial radio and film, talents join stage shows directed by notable film directors including Lamberto Avellana (1915-1991), Gerardo de Leon (1913-1981), and Manuel Conde (1915-1985). Stage shows are bodabil with a play at the end.

media_caption: Original cast members of Batibot, from left, Junix Inocian, Sienna Olaso, and at right, Bodjie Pascua, joined by puppets Kiko Matsing and Pong Pagong
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Philippine Children’s Television Foundation)
text_description: The longest running children’s show Batibot airs on RPN 9.

media_caption: Jay Taruc in i-Witness’s award-winning episode, “Batang Kalabaw,” 2008
text_description: The documentary i-Witness airs on GMA.

media_caption: Magazine ad featuring the original cast of Gulong ng Palad, 1977
text_description: Gulong ng Palad written by Lina Flor, and Ilaw ng Tahanan, written by Liwayway Arceo (1924 -1999), begin airing on DZRH, the first post-war soap operas on Philippine radio.

media_caption: Maja Salvador and Vilma Santos in a scene from Maalala Mo Kaya’s “Regalo” episode, 2006
text_description: The drama anthology of true-to-life stories Maala-ala Mo Kaya, airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Scene from Pin-Pin, 1990, with hosts Herbie Go, middle, and Shakespeare Ngo talking to Chinee K, a puppet character
text_description: The children’s program in Filipino and Hokkien, Pin-pin, airs on PTV 4.

media_caption: Scene from an episode of Hiraya Manawari, 1995
text_description: The children’s fantasy drama Hiraya Manawari airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Angelo Cometa, left, and Agatha Tapan in the “Jose Rizal: Sa Aking Mga Kababata” episode of Bayani, 1995
text_description: The history program Bayani begins its six-year run on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Cast of Sic O’Clock News
text_description: Sic O’Clock News, a TV news parody, airs on IBC13.

media_caption: Agot Isidro in a scene from Titser, 2013
text_description: The drama Titser, which examines the state of public education in the Philippines, airs on GMA News TV Channel 11.

media_caption: Sharlene San Pedro in an episode of Wansapanataym, 2014
text_description: The children’s fantasy series Wansapanataym airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Inside the radio booth of Go Teacher Go!, 2011
text_description: DZUP begins non-commercial shortwave radio broadcast at the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman.

media_caption: Hardcourt idols Alberto Guidaben and Robert Jaworski, 1975
text_description: BBC 2 begins live coverage of the Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) games.

media_caption: Thrilla in Manila, the boxing match between Joe Frazier, left, and Muhammad Ali, with Filipino referee Carlos Padilla Jr, center, 1975
text_description: RPN 9 broadcasts live the boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier dubbed Thrilla in Manila at the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City.

media_caption: Poster for the film adaptation of Reyna ng Vicks, 1958
text_description: Reyna ng Vicks airs on DZRH.

media_caption: Nestor de Villa and Nida Blanca on The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965
media_credit: (Pinoy Television, The Story of ABSCBN: The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.)
text_description: The musical-variety The Nida-Nestor Show airs on ABS-CBN Channel 3.

media_caption: Scene from John en Marsha
text_description: The sitcom John en Marsha begins its 17-year run on RPN 9.

media_caption: Host and producers of The Probe Team, from left, Tony Velasquez, Judith Torres, Cheche Lazaro, Maria Ressa, Kara Magsanoc-Alikpala, and David Celdran
text_description: Probe moves to GMA 7 and renames itself The Probe Team.

media_caption: MTRCB, headed by its chair, Eugenio Villareal, center, imposing strict measures on Pinoy Big Brother to protect minor housemates, 2015
text_description: The MTRCB orders ABS-CBN to attend a mandatory conference on gender sensitivity following the condemnation by the Philippine Commission on Women of the June 4 episode of the reality show Pinoy Big Brother: All In, where program participants are instructed to participate in a nude painting activity.

media_caption: Dely Magpayo on the set of Mga Liham Kay Tiya Dely, 1958
text_description: Fidela Magpayo (1920-2008) hosts a drama show with a new format, Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely, later renamed Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely on DZRH.

media_caption: Poster for the movie adaptation of Kuwentong Kutsero, 1952, with screenplay by Epifanio Matute
text_description: Si Aling Juanang Mapag-Impok, a soap-opera-cum advice program by Lina Flor (1914 -1976), and Kuwentong Kutsero, a satire on Philippine society and politics produced by Horacio de la Costa (1916-1977), go on the air.

media_caption: Public Forum director Marilou Diaz-Abaya, left, and host Randy David, with guests from the Philippine Tropical Fish Exporters’ Association
text_description: IBC 13 airs several firsts: Its documentary Ceasefire discusses a ceasefire between the military and the National Democratic Front-New People’s Army (NDF-NPA). Its public affairs program Truth Forum (later renamed Public Forum) becomes the first to use Filipino as language of serious discussion. Its magazine program Travel Time pioneers in travel shows. Its drama anthology program Lino Brocka Presents portrays realistic plots and characters.

media_caption: Cast of 5 and UP, 1992
media_credit: (GMA Gold: 50 Years of Broadcast History, edited by Chelo Banal-Formoso. GMA Network, 2001.)
text_description: 5 and Up, a tele-magazine hosted by kids ages 8 to 14, premieres on ABC5.

media_caption: Tessie Tomas and Noel Trinidad in Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, 1991
text_description: Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, a satirical sitcom, airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Poster for the movie adaptation of Aklat ng Pag-ibig, 1950
text_description: Another soap opera, Aklat ng Pag-ibig written by Genoveva Edroza Matute (1915-2009), airs on DZMB.

media_caption: Rosemarie Gil, left, Tita Muñoz, and Barbara Perez in an episode of Balintataw, 1967
media_credit: (Pinoy Television, The Story of ABS-CBN: The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.)
text_description: Balintataw, a joint venture between the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) and ABC Channel 5, begins airing original TV adaptations of Philippine literary pieces.

media_caption: Print advertisement for Balintataw
text_description: Radyo Balintataw, based on television’s Balintataw, airs on DZRH.

media_caption: Pres. Ferdinand Marcos and his generals on national television during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: The documentary Batas Militar airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Gel Santos-Relos and Atty. Renato Cayetano, hosts of Compañero y Compañera, 1997
text_description: The legal talk show Compañero y Compañera airs on DZMM, then a TV version on ABS-CBN follows.

media_caption: Pempe Padilla, left, Rita Amor, Jaime de la Rosa, and Lucas Paredes in the “Gregorio del Pilar” episode of Camay Theater in the Air, 1949
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of James de la Rosa/Baul ni Juan)
text_description: Camay Theater of the Air airs on DZBC, then moves to DZBB.

media_caption: Title card for the episode, “Panahon Na,” of Cheche Lazaro Presents, 2014
text_description: The magazine show Cheche Lazaro Presents airs on GMA 7, then moves to ABS-CBN in 2010.

media_caption: Scene from Chinatown TV, 2013
text_description: The magazine show Chinatown TV airs on IBC 13.

media_caption: Bataan National High School-Special Program for the Arts (BNHS-SPA) Dance Group on Concert at the Park in Rizal Park, 2016
text_description: Concert at the Park airs on GTV4, with simulcast on DZRB.

media_caption: Presentacion Bataclan as Priscilla, the “Kolynos Girl,” 1936
text_description: Musical programs dominate the programming of pioneer stations, such as Crystal Arcade on KZIB and KZRM’s The Kolynos Hour and The Listerine Hour. Most feature western popular music.

media_caption: Program logo for Mindalinaw, 2004
text_description: The talk show Mindalinaw, about people caught in conflicts in Mindanao, airs on DZMS, DZMY, and DXGO.

media_caption: Dr. Jaime Galvez Tan, second from left, host of Doctor’s Orders, 2007
text_description: Doctor’s Orders, a talk show about health, airs on DWWW.

media_caption: Pilita Corrales in An Evening with Pilita, 1964
media_credit: (Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN: The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.)
text_description: The musical-variety show An Evening with Pilita, the first to be videotaped, airs.

media_caption: Print advertisement for Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato, 1962
text_description: Considered the first soap opera on Philippine TV, Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato airs on ABS-CBN 3.

media_caption: Kuh Ledesma, 2012
text_description: The musical Kuh by Special Arrangement featuring Filipino popular music airs on IBC 13.

media_caption: Dennis Trillo, Carla Abellana, and Tom Rodriguez in a web advertisement of My Husband’s Lover, 2013
text_description: My Husband’s Lover, a telenovela on gay characters and dilemmas, airs on GMA7.

media_caption: Scene from the television adaptation of Noli Me Tangere, 1992, featuring Bodjie Pascua, left, Joel Torre, Ruben Rustia, and Cezar Xerez-Burgos, among others
text_description: The CCP produces several programs, including Pinoy Eh, a television magazine show on Filipino art and culture, and the 13-episode television drama series Noli Me Tangere based on Jose Rizal’s novel.

media_caption: JM Cobarrubias, Avi Siwa, and Jigs Mayuga, hosts of Out!, 2004
text_description: The first LGBTQ talk show in Southeast Asia, Out! airs on GMA 7.

media_caption: The Singing Brawners in an episode of Paco Park Presents, 2001
text_description: Paco Park Presents, a program of classical music, begins its 32-year run on MBS 4.

media_caption: Richard Gutierrez, host of Planet Philippines, 2009
text_description: Planet Philippines, a documentary about the environment, airs on GMA7.

media_caption: Inside a radio studio during an episode of Prinsipe Amante, 1953
text_description: The komedya Prinsipe Amante, written by Clodualdo del Mundo (1911-1977) airs on DZRH. It is later adapted into a komiks serial and two films.

media_caption: Inside the radio booth during an episode of Pugasan sa Kahanginan, 2014
text_description: Pugasan sa Kahanginan, a talk show for farmers in Bohol, Cebu and Negros Oriental, airs on DYHP.
Upon MacArthur’s landing, the Voice of Freedom operates under the call letters WVLC from Leyte.

media_caption: Chichay and Tolindoy in a promotional photo of Purico Troubadours, 1940s
text_description: Purico Troubadours/Purico Show, a daily variety show, begins airing on KZRH.

media_caption: Francisca “Babes” Custodio on Radyo Puplonganon, 2016
text_description: Radyo Puplonganon / Siday, featuring Waray poetry, airs on DYVL.

media_caption: Poster for the film adaptation of Recuerdo, 1953
text_description: Based on a komiks serial, the soap Recuerdo, written by Clodualdo del Mundo, airs on DZPI.

media_caption: An episode of Sugpuin ang Korupsyon, aka DiskArte, 2014, with hosts Henry Uri, left, and Flor Abanto, right, and guest Eva Mari Salvador, middle
text_description: The CCP produces award-winning Diskarte, formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon, on DZRH.

media_caption: Sunday, Sweet Sunday with guest Boots Anson, center, and hosts Jimmy Melendrez and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, 1973
text_description: The musical program Sunday, Sweet Sunday, the first TV program in the country to broadcast in color, airs.

media_caption: That’s Entertainment cast photo, 1986
media_credit: (Kuya Germs: 50 Years in Showbiz. GMA Network, 2013.)
text_description: The long-running teen-oriented variety show That’s Entertainment airs on GMA 7.

media_caption: Nikki Coseteng, host of Womanwatch, 2016
text_description: Radyo Womanwatch produced by activist women belonging to Women in Media Now airs on DZSR. The following year, Womanwatch airs on Channel 4.

media_caption: Arena Theater’s Sabina, Philippine Normal College, Manila, 1953
text_description: Arena Theater of the Philippines stages Severino Montano’s Sabina, Parting at Calamba, The Love of Leonor Rivera, and The Ladies and the Senator.
RCP merges with Far Eastern Radio Inc (FERI).
Nation Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) begins operations with DXYZ in Zamboanga and DZAM in Manila.

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card, signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
text_description: RCP opens KZRM and puts KZKZ off the air.

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
text_description: KZRM carries American and other foreign programs.

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
text_description: KZRM carries American and other foreign programs.

media_caption: Print advertisement of models of radio sets, with both long wave and short wave receivers, 1938
text_description: The Philippine Legislature passes a law to collect license fees from owners of radio sets.

media_caption: KZRH first aired from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila before World War II
text_description: H. E. Heacock Co. opens KZRH.

media_caption: KZRC station housed in the Gotiaoco Building (later Heacock Building) in Cebu City, 1940
text_description: KZRC re-opens under Heacock.

media_caption: Jai-Alai Building in Manila, 1952
text_description: Before retreating to Corregidor, MacArthur orders the destruction of radio equipment. Some KZRH equipment is brought to Corregidor while other pieces are hidden in the Jai-Alai building on Taft Avenue.

media_caption: Jai-Alai Building in Manila, 1952
text_description: The Japanese find radio equipment in the Jai-Alai building and put KZRH back on the air.
Radio Corporation of America (RCA) buys RCP.

media_caption: Ang Tinig ng Nayon, an agricultural program for radio produced by UP Los Baños
text_description: UP Los Baños establishes DZLB.
PIAM ceases broadcast.

media_caption: Joaquin Miguel Elizalde, one of the founders of the Manila Broadcasting Company
text_description: A new KZRH is back on the air under Joaquin and Manuel Elizalde’s Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC).

media_caption: Chichay and Tolindoy in a promotional photo of Purico Troubadours, 1940s
text_description: Purico Troubadours/Purico Show, a daily variety show, begins airing on KZRH.

media_caption: An edition of Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang
text_description: Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang airs on KZPI, then on DZRH until the 1960s. In 2007 it is revived on GMA 7, then DZRV and DZRH.

media_caption: James Lindenberg, regarded as one of the pioneers of commercial television in the Philippines
text_description: Due to import restrictions on TV equipment, Lindenberg focuses on radio and establishes DZBC

media_caption: Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart in a print advertisement of Glendale Butter, 1970
text_description: Robert “Bob” Stewart (1918-2006) establishes DZBB under the Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc.
The first TV station in the Philippines, ABS’s DZAQ-TV Channel 3, goes on the air.

media_caption: Nick Balbona, left, Eddie Ilarde, and Leila Benitez with guest international singer Pat Boone on Student Canteen, ca 1961
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of former senator Eddie Ilarde)
text_description: DZXL’s CBN Canteen, a 15-minute lunchtime musical program, debuts. When featured singer Priscilla Aristorenas moves to London, the program is reformatted as a talk-music show with Leila Benitez as host.

media_caption: Young Ramon Jacinto, founder of DZRJ
text_description: Ramon Jacinto begins operating DZRJ under the Rajah Broadcasting Network (RBN).

media_caption: Facade and reflecting pool of the Cultural Center of the Philippines
media_credit: (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977.)
text_description: Pres. Marcos inaugurates the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) as a venue for the performing arts.

media_caption: KBS-9: Accucolor 9 logo, 1969-1971
text_description: Benedicto acquires a legislative franchise to operate television station KBS-TV Channel 9 under KBS. ABS-CBN, until then airing on Channels 9 and 3, moves to Channels 2 and 4.

media_caption: Nora Aunor dancing on Superstar
text_description: The musical variety program Superstar, hosted by Nora Aunor, begins its 18-year run on Channel 9.

media_caption: Crowd in panic during the Plaza Miranda bombing, Manila, 21 Aug 1971
text_description: ABS-CBN Channel 2 covers the bombing of the Liberal Party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda.

media_caption: Orly Mercado, Cielito del Mundo, and Dr Antonio Talusan, hosts of Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko, 1976
text_description: Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko temporarily stops airing as the Marcos government spruces up for the International Monetary Fund-World Bank visit.

media_caption: Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon, hosts of Eat Bulaga!
text_description: Blocktimer Television and Production Exponents (TAPE Inc.) launches Eat Bulaga! on RPN 9.

media_caption: Funeral procession of Benigno Aquino Jr along Rizal Park, Manila, 1983
text_description: DZRV and other radio stations cover Aquino’s 12-hour funeral procession from the Santo Domingo Church in Quezon City to the Manila Memorial Park in Parañaque, but their signals are jammed. GMA 7 devotes eight seconds during its primetime news to the funeral.

media_caption: Michael Fajatin, second from left, and Jessica Soho, center, interviewing Bagong Alyansang Makabayan  Secretary-General Teddy Casiño, far left, during the 2001 EDSA Revolt
text_description: A popular uprising dubbed EDSA Revolt II ousts Pres Estrada.

media_caption: 1987 Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon trophy designed by Julie Lluch
text_description: The CCP launches the annual Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon.

media_caption: Cesar Montano, center, with Cesar Xerez-Burgos and Jaime Fabregas in Jose Rizal, 1998
text_description: · The docu-drama Jose Rizal, directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya (1955-2012), airs on GMA7 in celebration of the Philippine Centennial.

media_caption: MTRCB, headed by its chair, Eugenio Villareal, center, imposing strict measures on Pinoy Big Brother  to protect minor housemates, 2015
text_description: The MTRCB applies the classifications G (General Patronage), PG (Patnubay at Gabay, or Parental Guidance), and X (Disapproved for Airing) to television programs.

media_caption: Orly Mercado, Cielito del Mundo, and Dr Antonio Talusan, hosts of Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko, 1976
text_description: The GMA Channel 7 program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko features volunteer sign language interpreters, the first program to do so.

media_caption: Culture Carousel host and producer Irene Obligacion-Rada interviewing double bassist Kurt Muroki, 2012
text_description: The weekly radio program Culture Carousel airs on DZFE.

media_caption: Doc Nielsen Donato, one of the hosts of Born to Be Wild, 2007
text_description: GMA 7 airs Born to Be Wild, a pioneer in environmental magazine shows on television.

The Philippine Legislature enacts the Ship Radio Station Law, establishing the first radio regulatory office, the Radio Construction and Maintenance Section, under the Telegraph Division of the Bureau of Posts.
The Philippine Legislature creates the Board of Censorship for Moving Pictures (BCMP).
The Philippine Legislature enacts the Radio Control Law, shifting regulation of radio broadcasting from the Bureau of Posts to the newly created Radio Control Board.
Erlanger & Galinger opens KZEG, and features local opera and sarsuwela singers.
US President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s “fireside chats” go on air, the first to use radio to address audiences directly.
Balagtasan on the Air begins airing on KZRM.
The National Assembly changes BCMP’s name to Board of Review for Moving Pictures (BRMP) and expands its coverage to locally produced films distributed abroad.

Erlanger & Galinger sells KZRM and KZEG to Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC) of publisher J. Amado Araneta, marking the first cross-media ownership of radio and newspapers. He changes KZEG’s call letters to KZRF.

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Walang Sugat, CCP, Manila, 2012
text_description: KZRM covers live the sarsuwela Walang Sugat by Severino Reyes (1861-1942) at the Metropolitan Theater.

Iyo Karpo, the advice-dispensing radio character of Ben Zubiri (1911-1969), hosts Pangutan-a Ako and Purico Amateur Hour on KZRC. Zubiri gains fame as the composer and singer of the Cebuano classic Matud Nila.
The Commonwealth government opens KZND.
Philippine radio stations air news about the bombing of Pearl Harbor and, hours later, the Philippines.
Last days of December: All commercial radio programming ceases as the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) blows up radio transmitters and destroys equipment.
On the Voice of Freedom, Norman Reyes reads the historic announcement “Bataan Has Fallen,” written by Salvador P. Lopez, and translated and read in Tagalog by Francisco Isidoro.
Early May: The Voice of Freedom ceases broadcast. The Voice of Juan de la Cruz goes on the air. KZRC ceases broadcast.
The Japanese propaganda corps, the Hodobu, strictly monitors and controls radio, stage shows, printed media, and film.
The Voice of Juan de la Cruz ceases broadcast with the capture of its broadcasters.
The Philippine Symphony orchestra is formed and performs classical music over KZRH.
Declaring “independence” for the Philippines, the Japanese change the call letters of KZRH to PIAM.
Several mobile army stations are sent to Japan while the remaining stations are integrated into KZFM in Manila.
KZPI goes on test broadcast under the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC).
KZFM, KZRH, and KZPI cover the declaration of Philippine Independence and the inauguration of Pres Roxas.
The US government turns over KZFM to the Philippine government, under the office of Vice Pres. and Foreign Affairs Secretary Elpidio Quirino.

The Philippines requests the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) to replace its radio call letters from the American KZ to PI (Philippine Islands). The ITU instead grants the Philippines part of the D series, which until then was used exclusively by Germany.
The Department of Commerce and Industry takes jurisdiction over the Radio Control Division (RCD).
Pres. Roxas transfers KZFM to the newly created Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS) under the Office of the President.
KZRC re-opens in Cebu as an MBC affiliate.
KZAS, the first radio station in the Philippines with religious programming, goes on the air.
A second Cebu station, KZBU, opens under PBC.
All Philippine stations adopt the initial call letter D.
DXMV goes on the air in Cotabato City, the first radio station with a franchise to operate in Mindanao.
Local recording companies produce records of Philippine music.
The University of Santo Tomas (UST) establishes the Catholic station DZST.
The first detective drama on radio, Tony Narra, airs on DZBB.
Congress grants Lindenberg’s BEC a franchise to operate a radio and TV station.
The RCD, by then under the Radio Control Board, is transferred to the Department of Public Works and Communications (DPWC).
The Canoy brothers, Henry and Reuben, found the Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) with the first radio station in Cagayan de Oro City, DXCC.
Records of Mambo Magsaysay, the campaign jingle of Presidential candidate Ramon Magsaysay, are distributed free and aired almost everywhere in town fiestas.
A TV adaptation of Cyrano de Bergerac directed by James Reuter is broadcast live on ABS Channel 3 as the first drama program aired on Philippine TV.
Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc. expands and puts DZXX on the air.
ABS launches DZYL, the first radio station to broadcast via frequency modulation (FM).
RA 1476 abolishes the Radio Control Board but retains RCD under the DPWC.
CBN’s DZXL-TV Channel 9 begins broadcasting.

media_caption: Joaquin Miguel Elizalde, one of the founders of the Manila Broadcasting Company
text_description: The Elizalde brothers (Federico, Joaquin Miguel, and Manuel) establish DZRH-TV Channel 11.
Similar to the balagtasan, Cancionan on the Air airs on DWDW in Pangasinan.
The BRMP is renamed Board of Censors for Motion Pictures (BCMP), with jurisdiction expanded to include movies aired on TV.
Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc. establishes DZBB-TV Channel 7 with its first program, the dance show Dance Time with Chito, hosted by Chito Feliciano.
The DPWC renames the RCD Radio Control Office (RCO).
Mareco Broadcasting Network begins radio broadcasts and specializes in local music.
The Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc. is renamed Republic Broadcasting System (RBS).

The assassination and funeral of US Pres John F. Kennedy is covered live on TV. The non-stop four-day live coverage without commercial breaks transforms the way breaking news events are covered on global television
The National Media Production Center (NMPC) is created under the Office of the President.
RA 4379 establishes the Institute of Mass Communication in UP, the first to teach broadcasting in the Philippines. It will become the College of Mass Communication in 1988.
The NMPC acquires the facilities of the Voice of America in Malolos, Bulacan and begins operating it as the Voice of the Philippines (VOP) with the call letters DZRP.
ABS Channel 3 airs the first color TV transmission in the Philippines.
ABS and CBN stations officially merge as ABS-CBN.
ABS-CBN Channel 3 produces Halalan ’67, a 36-hour live nationwide television coverage of the results of the 1967 Congressional elections.
DZEC goes on the air under the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation for the Iglesia ni Cristo.
ABS-CBN airs the coverage of the assassination of US Senator Robert Kennedy via the first satellite transmission on Philippine TV.
The Ateneo Center for Educational TV begins transmitting televised lessons to schools through closed circuit transmission and via a microwave link to IBC TV-13.
The drama anthology Panagimpan airs on ABS-CBN.
The sitcom Tisoy, based on a satirical comic strip by Nonoy Marcelo (1939-2002), airs on ABC 5.
DZST is transferred to the Philippine Radio Educational and Information Center Inc (PREIC). Its call letters are changed to DZRV, for Radio Veritas.
RBS Channel 7 carries for Philippine television channels the satellite broadcast of the landing of the Apollo 11 spaceship on the moon.
Benedicto lists KBS in the Philippine Stock Exchange.
The long-running talk show for families of Overseas Filipino Workers, To Saudi with Love, airs on DZRH.
CBN airs the first live cooking show on TV, Let’s Cook with Nora, hosted by Nora Daza, later renamed Cooking It Up with Nora, enjoying a 25-year run.

Benedicto renames KBS Radio Philippines Network (RPN) and continues broadcast on Channel 9; begins a takeover of almost all the radio and television stations and facilities of the Lopezes throughout the country; and establishes Barangay Broadcasting Corporation (later Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation [BBC]), which starts airing on Channel 2.
KBS Channel 9 airs the live coverage of the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, West Germany.
Sen. Benigno Aquino Jr. aka Ninoy guests on Maximo Soliven’s program Impact on ABS-CBN Channel 2 to expose the plan of Pres. Marcos to declare martial law, called Operation Sagittarius.

Pres. Marcos moves RCO to the Board of Communications (BOC), the first quasi-judicial body with adjudicatory powers on matters involving telecommunication services. The BOC remains administratively under the DPWC.
Channels 7 and 13 resume broadcast while Channels 2, 4, 5, and 11 remain off the air. Local TV programs, with new titles that reflect what Marcos calls the New Society, are allowed to go on air.
Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran, the first public affairs talk show to be simulcast live by all radio and TV stations in the country, airs.

PD 36 cancels legislative franchises issued by Congress to radio and TV stations prior to the proclamation of martial law and requires all broadcast operations to obtain prior clearance from the newly-created Mass Media Council (MMC).
BBC Balita, the first primetime TV news in Filipino after the declaration of martial law, airs.
The execution of convicted drug lord Lim Seng is broadcast on television.
The Mass Media Advisory Council (MMAC) replaces the MMC. It issues permits for the operation of mass media in the Philippines, subject to Marcos’s approval.

The 1973 Constitution takes effect, banning foreigners from owning mass media in RP. Marcos presidential aide Gilberto M Duavit Sr, Stewart’s lawyer Felipe L Gozon, and his accountant Menardo R Jimenez buy the controlling interest in RBS from Stewart, an American.
The drama anthology Obra Maestra airs on BBC 2.
Government Television Network (GTV) is established, airs on Channel 4, with airtime shared by the Department of Public Information (DPI), the NMPC, and RPN.
Duavit, Gozon, and Jimenez rename RBS Greater Manila Area Radio-Television Arts (GMA-RTV), later shortened to GMA.
The RCO is renamed Telecommunications Control Bureau (TCB).
The MMAC is abolished and its powers are transferred to the Philippine Council for Print Media (PCPM) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC).
Benedicto buys the controlling interest in IBC and renames it Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) while the Canoys buy RMN back from Soriano.
The Marcos government establishes DWIM-FM.
The BCMP is run mostly by military personnel until 1981.
Benedicto inaugurates domestic satellite communications (DOMSAT) with RPN as the transmitting network of 11 satellite earth stations for all broadcasts from the Office of the President.
The Japanese robot animation program Voltes V airs on GMA7. Marcos will ban it a year later.
Benedicto ventures into cable television through Sining Makulay Inc.
The drama Marcelino Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro?, adapted from a Spanish novel, airs on BBC 2.
The drama anthology Rosas airs on GTV 4.
RPN 9 airs the first mini-series Malayo Pa ang Umaga.
Maskara, a drama anthology about the entertainment industry, airs on BBC 2.
Marcos creates the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications. The NTC integrates the functions of the BOC and the TCB.
RPN 9 airs a two-hour special on the animated version of the Iluko epic Biag ni Lam-ang.
The NTC is empowered to oversee technical matters concerning the broadcast media.
GTV is re-named Maharlika Broadcasting System (MBS), with NMPC in full control of the station and its airtime.
GMA 7 airs Lovingly Yours Helen, a drama anthology based on letters sent by viewers.
The BCMP is re-organized and re-named Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television (BRMPT).
The PCPM and the BMC are abolished. The power to grant broadcast franchises is given to the Batasang Pambansa.
DZRV airs the only blow-by-blow account of Aquino’s arrival, with its correspondent annotating the events through a pay phone.
Marcos announces on This Week with David Brinkley on American ABC-TV that a presidential snap election will be held.
The media cover the election campaign, the polling, the count, and the election aftermath.

The media cover the separate counts of the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) and the citizens’ group NAMFREL. TV and newspaper images of computer programmers walking out of the COMELEC count in protest strengthen public perception of a rigged tally in favor of Marcos.

Enrile asks DZRV to cover the announcement of his, and Ramos’s, break with Marcos. Cardinal Sin calls people via DZRV to protect Enrile and Ramos. By nightfall a siege is underway. Initially, only DZRV covers the event live, but provincial and foreign stations carry its signals.

As Marcos goes on air on MBS 4, he is interrupted by Gen Fabian Ver to ask permission to “annihilate” the rebels. The announcement is cut off by rebel troops who take over MBS 4 and, soon, other stations.
The media, including international media, cover the events at EDSA. Live broadcast signals from Manila are carried by provincial stations. The whole nation and the rest of the world watch and listen.
MBS is renamed People’s Television Channel 4 (PTV 4).
Cory Aquino’s government returns Channel 2 to the Lopezes and sequesters RPN 9 and IBC 13.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) produces and airs the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan on DZRV until 1992, then on DZRM until 1996. It highlights music and theater, discussions on issues in arts and culture, and balagtasan on current socio-political issues.
ABS-CBN resumes broadcast on Channel 2

Radio and TV cover the coup attempts live. In one of the attempts, DZRH reporter Rey Langit negotiates on the air with the rebels for a ceasefire to allow Department of Tourism Secretary Rafael Alunan to escort local and foreign tourists out of the battle zone in Makati.
Hamon sa Pamahalaan, Hamon sa Taumbayan, considered the first documentary to use the Filipino language, airs on IBC13.
The 1987 Philippine Constitution recognizes the vital role of communication and information in nation-building.
ABS-CBN 2 re-launches itself with the live musical special Star Network: Ang Pagbabalik ng mga Bituin.
DZUP, off the air since the declaration of martial law, resumes broadcast under the management of the UP IMC.
DZUP, off the air since the declaration of martial law, resumes broadcast under the management of the UP IMC.
Hilda Drama Specials anthology airs on RPN 9.
The CCP launches the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo.

Produced by the Ateneo Center for Social Policy and Public Affairs and the Foundation for Media Alternatives, the documentary Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan, airs on ABS-CBN. For its resolute anti-US bases stance, MTRCB Chair Manuel Morato bans the TV special.
The telemagazine Tatak Pilipino airs on ABS-CBN.
ABS-CBN expands into cable TV distribution by establishing SKYcable.
ABC returns to the air with the call sign DWET-TV and operates the Dream FM Network.
The first TV station to broadcast on the ultra-high frequency (UHF) band, Southern Broadcasting Network (SBN) Channel 21, goes on the air.
RMN launches DWKC-TV Channel 31 on UHF, the first to carry a movie format.
Rajah Broadcasting launches RJTV Channel 29 as an all-female and lifestyle station, the first to host home TV shopping.
ABS-CBN establishes Star Cinema as its filmmaking arm.
ABS-CBN launches Cinema One, a pay TV channel targeted at Filipinos overseas, on SkyCable.
The historical drama Bisperas ng Kasaysayan airs on RPN 9.
ABS-CBN Global Limited’s The Filipino Channel (TFC) is launched to cater to Filipinos worldwide.
ABS-CBN produces and distributes music by establishing Star Records.
GMA launches DWDB-TV Channel 27 on UHF, called CityNet TV from 1995 to 1999, Entertainment Music Channel (EMC) from 1999 to 2001, and back as CityNet in 2005, as GMA’s outlet for imported programs.
Tinig ng Nursia: Women’s Studies on the Air, produced by St. Scholastica’s College, airs on DWSS.
GMA Network establishes GMA Films.
The Mexican telenovela Marimar airs on RPN 9, shifting television’s late afternoon and evening primetime programming and ushering in the dubbing industry in the country.
The talk show Isip Pinoy airs on RPN 9.
ABS-CBN launches Sarimanok News Network (SNN), now ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC), as the Philippines’ first 24/7 news channel on SkyCable.
ABS-CBN acquires Studio 23 on the UHF band.
ABS-CBN launches ABS-CBN Interactive (ABS-CBNi, later ABS-CBN Digital Media) as its digital and internet subsidiary.
ABS-CBN launches the Lifestyle Network channel on SKYcable.
ABS-CBN launches the Knowledge Channel on SKYcable.
Filipinos witness through live radio and television coverage an elected president stand trial.
DZRV’s Pitlag! Kwento ng Buhay becomes the first Philippine radio program to win an international award in a NY Festival.
Pres. Estrada’s trial continues on live radio and television.
Cardinal Sin calls on the people via DZRV to once again rebel against a president, this time Joseph Estrada, following accusations of massive corruption.
PTV 4 is rebranded as National Broadcasting Network (NBN).
IBC 13 airs Amazing Twins, the first Chinese telenovela in the Philippines.
The children’s magazine show Usapang Pambata airs on DXMD in Kidapawan and DXMS in Cotabato.
Greater Manila Area Radio-Television Arts (GMA) Channel 7 changes its name to Global Media Arts (GMA) Channel 7.
Both ABS-CBN and GMA send journalists to cover the US invasion of Iraq.
The Chinese telenovela Meteor Garden airs on ABS-CBN. Other chinovelas from Taiwan and koreanovelas from South Korea follow.

A group led by Antonio Cojuangco Jr, former chair of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) and owner of Dream Satellite Broadcasting, acquires ABC. He retains ownership of Dream FM Network, but later sells it to Ultrasonic Broadcasting System.

A stampede of mostly impoverished 30,000 fans at the entrance of the Philippine Sports Stadium on the anniversary of the television game show Wowowee kills 73 and injures 392. Featuring games promising instant wealth, the show and its host Willy Revillame as well as ABS-CBN are widely criticized not only for acts detrimental to public health, public welfare, and public safety, but also for capitalizing on the despair of the poor.
GMA launches its first international channel, GMA Pinoy TV.
GMA CityNet changes its name to Channel Q, a lifestyle channel for women.
The CCP produces the children’s radio show Wan Dey Isang Araw on DZAS.
The radio drama Pinoy Klasiks, based on Filipino literary classics, airs on DZAS.
ABS-CBN establishes Hero TV channel on SKYcable.
ABC relaunches as TV5 under ABC Development Corporation.
ABS-CBN merges radio and television through DZMM Teleradyo on SKYCable.

Cojuangco's group sells its share to PLDT’s broadcasting division, Media Quest Holdings Incorporated, owned by Manuel V Pangilinan. TV5 is rebranded as the Kapatid network while its radio station is branded as Radyo Singko.
Media Quest shifts FM programming from mainly music to news and talk, a format traditionally used in AM radio.
GMA News TV Channel 27 replaces QTV-11 and Channel Q.

media_caption: Scene from the film adaptation of Edong Mapangarap, 1950, with screenplay by Virgilio “Beer” Flores
text_headline: First radio stations go on air in Manila.
text_description: First radio stations go on air in Manila with radio serials by Lina Flor (1914-76), Genoveva Edroza-Matute (1915-2009), Liwayway Arceo (1924-99), and Horacio de la Costa (1916-77).. Later, many radio programs are made into films, like Edong Mapangarap, Prinsipe Amante, and Gulong ng Palad.
